display_description.en: Air or atmospheric pressure is the pressure exerted by overlying air. (IOOS)
Air pressure at mean sea level is the atmospheric pressure at sea level at a given location. (NOAA)

display_name.en: Air pressure at mean sea level

display_description.en: Air temperature is the temperature of air in situ. (IOOS)
Colored (or chromophoric) dissolved organic matter (CDOM) is the optically measurable component of the dissolved organic matter in water. (IOOS)
Dew point temperature is the temperature at which water vapor in air begins to condense. (IOOS)
A velocity is a vector quantity. 'Eastward' indicates a vector component which is positive when directed eastward (negative westward). (CF)
Dissolved oxygen (DO) saturation is DO concentration relative to DO saturation levels at the same temperature and salinity in a water sample. (IOOS)
Latitude is the Y-coordinate of dependent observation in geographic coordinate. North is positive. (IOOS)
Altitude is the Z-coordinate of observation in vertical distance above reference. Up is positive. (IOOS)
Longitude is the X-coordinate of dependent observation in geographic coordinate. East is positive. (IOOS)
Chlorophyll is the green pigment found in plants and algae. Chlorophyll measurements are used to determine how much algae is in the water. (USGS)
Dissolved oxygen (DO) refers to the concentration of oxygen gas incorporated in water. (EPA)
A velocity is a vector quantity. 'Northward' indicates a vector component which is positive when directed northward (negative southward). (CF)
Relative humidity is the amount of moisture in the air as vapor relative to how much it can possibly hold at the same temperature. (IOOS)
Sea surface temperature is usually abbreviated as 'SST'. It is the temperature of sea [or lake] water near the surface (including the part under sea-ice, if any). (CF)

Temperature measured by an infrared radiometer typically operating at wavelengths in the range 3.7 - 12 micrometers. It represents the temperature within the conductive diffusion-dominated sub-layer at a depth of approximately 10 - 20 micrometers below the air-sea interface. Measurements of this quantity are subject to a large potential diurnal cycle including cool skin layer effects (especially at night under clear skies and low wind speed conditions) and warm layer effects in the daytime. (CF)
Wave direction is the direction that the wind-waves are coming from. (NOAA)
Dominant wave direction is the direction from which the most energetic waves are coming. (CF)
Dominant wave directional spread
Mean wave directional spread

Wave height is defined as the vertical distance from a wave trough to the following wave crest. The maximum wave height is the greatest trough to crest distance measured during the observation period. (CF def)

The maximum wave period is the longest wave period measured during the observation period. A period is an interval of time, or the time-period of an oscillation. Wave period is the interval of time between repeated features on the waveform such as crests, troughs or upward passes through the mean level. (CF def)

Wave height is defined as the vertical distance from a wave trough to the following wave crest. The height of the highest tenth is defined as the mean of the highest ten percent of trough to crest distances measured during the observation period. (CF def)

display_name.en: Mean wave height of highest tenth

display_description.en: A period is an interval of time, or the time-period of an oscillation. Wave period is the interval of time between repeated features on the waveform such as crests, troughs or upward passes through the mean level. Wave mean period is the mean period measured over the observation duration. (CF def)
The dominant wave period represents the most energetic wave in the spectrum. (NOAA)
Significant wave height is the average of the highest one-third (33%) of waves (measured from trough to crest) that occur in a given period. (NOAA)

Significant wave period is a statistic computed from wave measurements and corresponds to the mean wave period of the highest one-third of the waves. A period is an interval of time, or the time-period of an oscillation. Wave period is the interval of time between repeated features on the waveform such as crests, troughs or upward passes through the mean level. (CF def)

Conductivity is the ability of a material to pass an electrical current. It is the inverse of resistance. In water, it is a proxy from which salinity is derived for water quality or to further derive water density. (IOOS)
pH is a measure of the acidity or alkalinity of the seawater. (NOAA)

In the atmosphere, the partial pressure of carbon dioxide (pCO₂) is defined as the pressure the CO₂ would exert if all other gases were removed. In the ocean (/lake), the pCO₂ is determined by the amount of dissolved CO₂ and H₂CO₃. (IOOS)
River discharge is the volumetric rate of water flow of a stream or river or pipe. The measure of flow through a cross-sectional area per unit time. (IOOS)
Sea water density is the in-situ density. (CF def)
The pressure that exists in the medium of sea water due to overlying sea water. Excludes the pressure due to sea ice, air and any other medium that may be present. (CF def)
The pressure that exists in the medium of sea water. It includes the pressure due to overlying sea water, sea ice, air and any other medium that may be present. (CF def)
Water temp is the in-situ temperature of the ocean [or lake]. (IOOS)
Turbidity is a measure of light scattering due to suspended material in water. It is a measure of the cloudiness of water. (IOOS)

Secchi depth is a measure of visibility or transparency in water. A Secchi Disk is a patterned disk that is lowered into the water and the depth at which the pattern is no longer visible is the called the Secchi Disk depth (SDD). (IOOS)

Downwelling radiation is radiation from above. Shortwave is a term used to describe the radiant energy emitted by the sun in the visible and near-ultraviolet wavelengths. A radiative flux is sometimes referred to as 'irradiance.'

Upwelling irradiance is irradiance from below. Shortwave is a term used to describe the radiant energy emitted by the sun in the visible and near-ultraviolet wavelengths. A radiative flux is sometimes referred to as 'irradiance.'
Upwelling radiation is radiation from below. Longwave indicates infrared radiation. A radiative flux is sometimes called 'irradiance.'
Downwelling radiation is radiation from above. Longwave indicates infrared radiation. A radiative flux is sometimes called 'irradiance.'

'Longwave' means ifrared radiation. 'Downward' indicates a vector component which is positive when directed downward (negative upward). Net downward radiation is the difference between radiation from above (downwelling) and radiation from below (upwelling). A radiative flux is sometimes called 'irradiance.' (CF def)

'Shortwave' means shortwave radiation. 'Downward' indicates a vector component which is positive when directed downward (negative upward). Net downward radiation is the difference between radiation from above (downwelling) and radiation from below (upwelling). A radiative flux is sometimes called 'irradiance.' (CF def)

Net downward radiation is the difference between radiation from above (downwelling) and radiation from below (upwelling). Radiative flux is the sum of shortwave and longwave radiative fluxes. (CF def)
The albedo is the fraction of the shortwave radiation arriving at the land surface that is reflected back into the atmosphere. (USACE)
Precipitation is the amount of liquid rain that has accumulated over the measurement period.
Precipitation rate is the amount of wet equivalent preciptation per unit time. (IOOS def)

Photosynthetically available radiation, or PAR, is the integrated downwelling irradiance for wavelengths from 400 to 700nm. It is the energy from the visible portion of sunlight that is available for photosynthesis [n water]. (IOOS)

Photosynthetically available radiation, or PAR, is the integrated downwelling irradiance for wavelengths from 400 to 700nm. It is the energy from the visible portion of sunlight that is available for photosynthesis [n water]. (IOOS)
Sea water currents are the directional movements of water. Currents at the surface is the direction and speed of the water at the surface (<1 meter deep).
Sea water currents are the directional movements of water. Currents at the surface is the direction and speed of the water at the surface (<1 meter deep).
Backscatter is the measure of sound that is reflected by the sea floor and received by the sonar. (NOAA)
Backscatter is the measure of sound that is reflected by the sea floor and received by the sonar. (NOAA)
Pressure Tendency
A velocity is a vector quantity. 'Upward' indicates a vector component which is positive when directed upward (negative downward). (CF)
Atmospheric visibility is the distance an object can be seen and identified. (IOOS)

Wind chill is the perceived air temperature when wind is factored in with the ambient air temperature (which makes it feel colder than the actual air temperature). Wind chill is based on the rate of heat loss from exposed skin caused by wind and cold. (CF)
Wind direction is the direction from which wind is blowing. It is a meteorological convention (degrees clockwise from North). (IOOS)
Wind speed is the magnitude of wind velocity. Wind is motion of air relative to the surface of the earth. (IOOS)
Wind gust speed is the maximum instantaneous wind speed (usually no more than but not limited to 10 seconds) within a sample averaging interval. (IOOS)
Salinity refers to the salt content of a water sample or body of water. (NOAA)
Depth is the Z-coordinate of observation in vertical distance below reference. Down is positive. (IOOS)
Depth is the Z-coordinate of observation in vertical distance below reference. Down is positive. (IOOS)
Latitude is the Y-coordinate of dependent observation in geographic coordinate. North is positive. (IOOS)
Sea ice percent coverage
Longitude is the X-coordinate of dependent observation in geographic coordinate. East is positive. (IOOS)

Conductivity is the ability of a material to pass an electrical current. Conductivity can be corrected to a reference temperature. When this reference temperature is 25 degrees Celsius it is often referred to as 'specific conductivity'.
FDOM refers to  the fluorescent fraction of colored DOM (referred to as CDOM fluorescence or FDOM) (IOOS)
ID of a Innovasea Fathom fish tag
Specific conductivity is conductivity at 25 °C, meaning that at any temperature for which the measurement is made, the value is corrected to what it would be at 25 ºC (USGS).

Phycocyanin is a pigment found in cyanobacteria that is measured in freshwater environments. The phycocyanin measurement is used as a field screening for cyanobacteria and cyanobacteria blooms, also called blue green algae. (EPA)
Current speed is the speed at which the water is flowing. It is calculated from the eastward and northward vector components.
Current direction is the direction from which the water is flowing. It is calculated from the eastward and northward vector components.

Phycocyanin is a pigment found in cyanobacteria that is measured in freshwater environments. The phycocyanin measurement is used as a field screening for cyanobacteria and cyanobacteria blooms, also called blue green algae. (EPA)

Phycocyanin is a pigment found in cyanobacteria that is measured in freshwater environments. The phycocyanin measurement is used as a field screening for cyanobacteria and cyanobacteria blooms, also called blue green algae. (EPA)
Redox (oxidation and reduction) potential of seawater in millivolts. (NOAA)
Microcystins are toxins produced by a number of cyanobacteria species. (EPA)
Microcystin estimate
Microcystin Lower Limit of Detection

Pore size fraction (upper)
Pore size fraction (lower)
Microcystin LLOQ
Suspended particulate matter
The upper limit of quantification for microcystin.
Minimum depth of sampling for presented data
Maximum depth of sampling for presented data
Battery voltage of a sensor system or datalogger that is recorded as an indicator of sensor health and data reliability. (IOOS)
Chlorophyll is the green pigment in plants and algae. Chlorophyll measurements are used to determine how much algae is in the water. (USGS)
Dissolved organic carbon
This is the concentration of nitrate (NO₃⁻) in a water sample. (IOOS)
This is the concentration of phosphate (PO₄⁳⁻) in a water sample. (IOOS)
This is the concentration of ammonium (NH₄⁺) in a water sample. (IOOS)
This is the concentration of ammonia (NH₃) in a water sample. (IOOS)
The concentration of total phosphorus (TP) represents the sum of organic and inorganic phosphorus compounds in a water sample. (IOOS)
The concentration of nitrite and nitrate (NO₂⁻ + NO₃⁻) in a water sample. (IOOS)
The concentration of total nitrogen (TN) represents the sum of organic and inorganic nitrogen compounds in a water sample. (IOOS)
Total suspended solids (TSS) are organic and inorganic solids that suspend in water. They can be silt, phytoplankton, and waste. (IOOS)
Surface elevation is the height or altitude of the sea surface above a specified reference. (IOOS)
